query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Non era ancor di là Nesso arrivato, 2 quando noi ci mettemmo per un bosco 3 che da neun sentiero era segnato.
query.result: 1 Not yet had Nessus arrived there, 2 when we set ourselves to a forest 3 that was marked by a new path.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Non han sì aspri sterpi né sì folti 8 quelle fiere selvagge che ’n odio hanno 9 tra Cecina e Corneto i luoghi cólti.
query.result: 7 Do not have such rough brambles nor such dense 8 those wild beasts that in hatred have 9 between Cecina and Corneto the cultivated places.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Quivi le brutte Arpie lor nidi fanno, 11 che cacciar de le Strofade i Troiani 12 con tristo annunzio di futuro danno.
query.result: 10 There the ugly Harpies make their nests, 11 that drove the Trojans from the Strophades 12 with a sad announcement of future harm.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Ali hanno late, e colli e visi umani, 14 piè con artigli, e pennuto ’l gran ventre; 15 fanno lamenti in su li alberi strani.

Please translate each line literally into English.
16 E ’l buon maestro «Prima che più entre, 17 sappi che se’ nel secondo girone», 18 mi cominciò a dire, «e sarai mentre
19 che tu verrai ne l’orribil sabbione.
query.result:
16 And the good master “Before you enter more, 17 know that you are in the second circle,” 18 began to say to me, “and you will be while
19 that you come to the horrible sandy ground.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
20 Però riguarda ben; sì vederai 21 cose che torrien fede al mio sermone».
22 Io sentia d’ogne parte trarre guai 23 e non vedea persona che ’l facesse; 24 per ch’io tutto smarrito m’arrestai.
query.result:
20 Therefore look well; you will see 21 things that would restore faith to my sermon.
22 I heard from every part drawing groans 23 and I saw no one who made them; 24 for which I, all lost, stopped myself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Cred’ ïo ch’ei credette ch’io credesse 26 che tante voci uscisser, tra quei bronchi, 27 da gente che per noi si nascondesse.
query.result: 25 I believe that he believed that I believed 26 that so many voices came forth, among those throats, 27 from people who hid themselves for us.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Però disse ’l maestro: «Se tu tronchi 29 qualche fraschetta d’una d’este piante, 30 li pensier c’hai si faran tutti monchi».
query.result: 28 Therefore said the master: “If you break 29 some small branch of one of these plants, 30 the thoughts that you have will all become maimed.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Allor porsi la mano un poco avante 32 e colsi un ramicel da un gran pruno; 33 e ’l tronco suo gridò: «Perché mi schiante?».

Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Da che fatto fu poi di sangue bruno, 35 ricominciò a dir: «Perché mi scerpi? 36 non hai tu spirto di pietade alcuno?
37 Uomini fummo, e or siam fatti sterpi: 38 ben dovrebb’ esser la tua man più pia, 39 se state fossimo anime di serpi».
query.result:
34 From when it was then made of dark blood, 35 he began again to say: “Why do you drain me? 36 do you not have any spirit of pity?
37 We were men, and now we are made thorns; 38 well should your hand be more pious, 39 if we were staying as the souls of serpents.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Come d’un stizzo verde ch’arso sia 41 da l’un de’ capi, che da l’altro geme 42 e cigola per vento che va via,
43 sì de la scheggia rotta usciva insieme 44 parole e sangue; ond’ io lasciai la cima 45 cadere, e stetti come l’uom che teme.
query.result:
40 As of a green twig that is burned 41 from one of the ends, which from the other groans 42 and creaks for the wind that goes away,
43 thus from the broken splinter came forth together 44 words and blood; whence I let the top 45 fall, and stood as the man who fears.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 «S’elli avesse potuto creder prima», 47 rispuose ’l savio mio, «anima lesa, 48 ciò c’ha veduto pur con la mia rima,
49 non averebbe in te la man distesa; 50 ma la cosa incredibile mi fece 51 indurlo ad ovra ch’a me stesso pesa.
query.result:
46 “If they had been able to believe before,” 47 responded my wise one, “injured soul, 48 that which he has seen also with my rhyme,
49 would not have had the hand extended in you; 50 but the incredible thing made him 51 lead to a work that weighs on me myself.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Ma dilli chi tu fosti, sì che ’n vece 53 d’alcun’ ammenda tua fama rinfreschi 54 nel mondo sù, dove tornar li lece».
query.result: 52 But tell him who you were, so that in place 53 of some amends your fame refreshes 54 in the world above, where to return is permitted.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 E ’l tronco: «Sì col dolce dir m’adeschi, 56 ch’i’ non posso tacere; e voi non gravi 57 perch’ ïo un poco a ragionar m’inveschi.
query.result: 55 And the trunk: “Yes, with sweet speech you entice me, 56 that I cannot be silent; and you do not weigh heavily 57 because I a little grow old in speaking.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Io son colui che tenni ambo le chiavi 59 del cor di Federigo, e che le volsi, 60 serrando e diserrando, sì soavi,
61 che dal secreto suo quasi ogn’ uom tolsi; 62 fede portai al glorïoso offizio, 63 tanto ch’i’ ne perde’ li sonni e ’ polsi.
query.result:
58 I am the one who held both the keys 59 of the heart of Frederick, and who turned them, 60 locking and unlocking, so sweetly,
61 that from his secret almost every man took [knowledge]; 62 faith I bore to the glorious office, 63 so much that I lost my sleep and my pulses.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 La meretrice che mai da l’ospizio 65 di Cesare non torse li occhi putti, 66 morte comune e de le corti vizio,
67 infiammò contra me li animi tutti; 68 e li ’nfiammati infiammar sì Augusto, 69 che ’ lieti onor tornaro in tristi lutti.
query.result:
64 The courtesan who never from the shelter 65 of Caesar turned her beautiful eyes, 66 common death and the vice of the courts,
67 inflamed against me all the spirits; 68 and the inflamed inflamed so Augustus, 69 that the happy honors turned into sad mourning.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 L’animo mio, per disdegnoso gusto, 71 credendo col morir fuggir disdegno, 72 ingiusto fece me contra me giusto.
query.result: 70 My spirit, for disdainful taste, 71 believing with dying to flee disdain, 72 unjustly made me just against myself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Per le nove radici d’esto legno 74 vi giuro che già mai non ruppi fede 75 al mio segnor, che fu d’onor sì degno.
query.result: 73 By the nine roots of this wood 74 I swear to you that I never broke faith 75 to my lord, who was so worthy of honor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 E se di voi alcun nel mondo riede, 77 conforti la memoria mia, che giace 78 ancor del colpo che ’nvidia le diede».
query.result: 76 And if anyone of you returns to the world, 77 comfort my memory, which lies 78 still from the blow that envy gave it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Un poco attese, e poi «Da ch’el si tace», 80 disse ’l poeta a me, «non perder l’ora; 81 ma parla, e chiedi a lui, se più ti piace».

Please translate each line literally into English.
82 Ond’ ïo a lui: «Domandal tu ancora 83 di quel che credi ch’a me satisfaccia; 84 ch’i’ non potrei, tanta pietà m’accora».

Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Perciò ricominciò: «Se l’om ti faccia 86 liberamente ciò che ’l tuo dir priega, 87 spirito incarcerato, ancor ti piaccia
88 di dirne come l’anima si lega 89 in questi nocchi; e dinne, se tu puoi, 90 s’alcuna mai di tai membra si spiega».
query.result:
85 Therefore he began again: “If the man makes 86 freely that which your saying begs, 87 spirit imprisoned, may it still please you
88 to tell how the soul binds itself 89 in these knots; and tell, if you can, 90 if ever any of such limbs are unfolded.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Allor soffiò il tronco forte, e poi 92 si convertì quel vento in cotal voce: 93 «Brievemente sarà risposto a voi.
query.result: 91 Then the strong trunk blew, and then 92 was converted that wind into such a voice: 93 Briefly will be answered to you.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Quando si parte l’anima feroce 95 dal corpo ond’ ella stessa s’è disvelta, 96 Minòs la manda a la settima foce.
query.result: 94 When the fierce soul departs 95 from the body from which it has unveiled itself, 96 Minos sends it to the seventh ditch.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.

106 Qui le strascineremo, e per la mesta 107 selva saranno i nostri corpi appesi, 108 ciascuno al prun de l’ombra sua molesta».

query.result:
109 We were still at the trunk waiting, 110 believing that he wished to say something else, 111 when we were surprised by a rumor,

Please translate each line literally into English.

query.result:
118 That one ahead: “Now hurry, hurry, death!” 119 And the other, to whom it seemed to delay too much, 120 cried: “Lano, your legs were not swift at the games from Toppo!”
121 were not attentive/careful.

122 E poi che forse li fallia la lena, 123 di sé e d’un cespuglio fece un groppo.

query.result:

query.result: 130 I pressed then my escort by the hand, 131 and led me to the bush that wept 132 for the bleeding breaks in vain.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 «O Iacopo», dicea, «da Santo Andrea, 134 che t’è giovato di me fare schermo? 135 che colpa ho io de la tua vita rea?».
query.result: 133 “O James,” he said, “from Saint Andrew, 134 what has it profited you to make a shield of me? 135 what guilt do I have of your guilty life?”

query.prompt:

query.result: 136 When the master was above him firm, 137 he said: “Who were you, that through so many points 138 you puff with bloody painful speech?”

query.result:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
143 I’ fui de la città che nel Batista 144 mutò ’l primo padrone; ond’ ei per questo
145 sempre con l’arte sua la farà trista; 146 e se non fosse che ’n sul passo d’Arno 147 rimane ancor di lui alcuna vista,
148 que’ cittadin che poi la rifondarno 149 sovra ’l cener che d’Attila rimase, 150 avrebber fatto lavorare indarno.
query.result:
143 I was from the city that in the Baptist 144 changed the first lord; for which reason she, for this,
145 always with her art will make it sad; 146 and if it were not that on the step of Arno 147 remains still some sight of him,
148 those citizens who then refounded it 149 over the ashes that of Attila remained, 150 would have had worked in vain.

151 Io fei gibetto a me de le mie case».
query.result: 151 I made a gallows for myself of my houses.
